medical: CC: Headache. HX: This 51 y/o RHM was moving furniture several days prior to presentation when he struck his head (vertex) against a door panel. He then stepped back and struck his back on a trailer hitch. There was no associated LOC but he felt "dazed." He complained a HA since the accident. The following day he began experiencing episodic vertigo lasting several minutes with associated nausea and vomiting. He has been lying in bed most of the time since the accident. He also complained of transient left lower extremity weakness. The night before admission he went to his bedroom and his girlfriend heard a loud noise. She found him on the floor unable to speak or move his left side well. He was taken to a local ER. In the ER experienced a spell in which he stared to the right for approximately one minute. During this time he was unable to speak and did not seem to comprehend verbal questions. This resolved. ER staff noted decreased left sided movement and a left Babinski sign. He was given valium 5 mg, and DPH 1.0g. A HCT was performed and he was transferred to UIHC. PMH: DM, Coronary Artery Disease, Left femoral neuropathy of unknown etiology. Multiple head trauma in past (?falls/fights). MEDS: unknown oral med for DM. SHX: 10+pack-year h/o Tobacco use; quit 2 years ago. 6-pack beer/week. No h/o illicit drug use. FHX: unknown. EXAM: 70BPM, BP144/83, 16RPM, 36.0C MS: Alert and oriented to person, place, time. Fluent speech. CN: left lower facial weakness with right gaze preference. Pupils 3/3 decreasing to 2/2 on exposure to light. Optic disks flat. MOTOR: decreased spontaneous movement of left-sided extremities. 5/4 strength in both upper and lower extremities. Normal muscle tone and bulk. SENSORY: withdrew equally to noxious stimulation in all four extremities. GAIT/STATION/COORDINATION: not tested. The general physical exam was unremarkable. During the exam the patient experienced a spell during which his head turned and eyes deviated to the leftward, and his right hand twitched. The entire spell lasted one minute. During the episode he was verbally unresponsive. He appeared groggy and lethargic after the event. HCT without contrast: 11/18/92: right frontal skull fracture with associated minimal epidural hematoma and small subdural hematoma, as well as some adjacent subarachnoid blood and brain contusion. LABS: CBC, GS, PT/PTT were all WNL. COURSE: The patient was diagnosed with a right frontal SAH/contusion and post traumatic seizures. DPH was continued and he was given a Librium taper for possible alcoholic withdrawal. A neurosurgical consult was obtained. He did not receive surgical intervention and was discharged 12/1/92. Neuropsychological testing on 11/25/92 revealed: poor orientation to time or place and poor attention. Anterograde verbal and visual memory was severely impaired. Speech became mildly dysarthric when fatigued. Defective word finding. Difficulty copying 2 of 3 three dimensional figures. Recent head injury as well as a history of ETOH abuse and multiple prior head injuries probably contribute to his deficits.
layman:
**Chief complaint:** Headache.  

**History of present illness:**  
A 51‑year‑old man was moving furniture a few days before he came to the hospital. He hit the top of his head on a door, then hit his back on a trailer hitch. He did not lose consciousness but felt dazed. He has had a headache since the accident. The next day he had brief episodes of dizziness that lasted a few minutes and were accompanied by nausea and vomiting. He has been mostly in bed since then. He also said his left leg felt weak for a short time. The night before he was admitted, his girlfriend heard a loud noise and found him on the floor, unable to speak or move his left side well. He was taken to a local emergency department. There he had a one‑minute episode where he stared to the right, could not speak, and seemed not to understand questions. The episode stopped. The ER doctors saw that his left side moved less and he had a positive Babinski sign. They gave him 5 mg of Valium and 1 g of DPH. A head CT was done and he was sent to UIHC.

**Past medical history:**  
- Diabetes  
- Coronary artery disease  
- Left femoral nerve damage of unknown cause  
- Several previous head injuries (possibly from falls or fights)  

**Medications:**  
He takes an oral diabetes medicine, but the exact name is unknown.

**Social history:**  
- Smoked more than 10 packs of cigarettes in his life; quit two years ago.  
- Drinks about six beers a week.  
- No history of illegal drug use.

**Family history:**  
Unknown.

**Physical exam:**  
- Heart rate 70 bpm, blood pressure 144/83 mm Hg, breathing 16 breaths/min, temperature 36.0 °C.  
- Awake, aware of himself, where he is, and the time.  
- Spoke normally.  
- Neurologic exam: weakness in the lower part of his left face and a tendency to look to the right. Both pupils were 3 mm and got smaller to 2 mm when light was shone. Optic discs looked normal. Muscle movement was weaker on the left side. Strength was 5/4 in all arms and legs. Muscle tone and size were normal. He reacted the same to painful touch in all four limbs. We did not test his walking, standing, or coordination. The rest of the physical exam was normal.  
- While we were examining him, he had a one‑minute episode where his head turned, his eyes looked left, and his right hand twitched. He could not speak during that time. After the episode he seemed drowsy and tired.

**Head CT (no contrast) on 11/18/92:**  
- Fracture of the right frontal part of the skull.  
- Small epidural bleed.  
- Small subdural bleed.  
- Some blood in the space around the brain.  
- Bruise on the brain.

**Laboratory tests:**  
CBC, electrolytes, PT/PTT were all within normal limits.

**Course:**  
He was diagnosed with a right frontal subarachnoid bleed, brain bruise, and seizures after the injury. He kept taking DPH and was given a taper of Librium to help with possible alcohol withdrawal. A neurosurgeon was consulted but he did not need surgery. He was discharged on 12/1/92.

**Neuropsychological testing on 11/25/92:**  
- Trouble knowing the time or place.  
- Poor attention.  
- Severe problems with new verbal and visual memory.  
- Mild slurred speech when tired.  
- Trouble finding words.  
- Difficulty copying two of three 3‑D shapes.  

His recent head injury, alcohol abuse, and many earlier head injuries likely caused these problems.
